data.title: John George Bannerman Diefenbaker (1895-1979)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for John Diefenbaker born 1895 Neustadt, Grey, Ontario, Canada died 1979 Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, Canada including ancestors + 1 photos + 2 genealogist comments + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors

Profile last modified 7 Feb 2024 | Created 30 Mar 2014

This page has been accessed 3,050 times.

Biography

John Diefenbaker is Notable.

John Diefenbaker, a lawyer and Progressive Conservative Party politician, was born September 18, 1895, in Neustadt, Ontario. He was the elder son of William Diefenbaker and Mary Bannerman. On June 29, 1929, he married Edna Mae Brower in Toronto. On December 8, 1953, he married Olive Evangeline Palmer, née Freeman. There were no children from either marriage. He had a stepdaughter, Carolyn Diefenbaker, Olive's daughter. He died August 16, 1979, in Ottawa.

John Diefenbaker, avocat et homme politique, né le 18 septembre 1895 à Neustadt, Ontario, fils aîné de William Diefenbaker et Mary Bannerman ; le 29 juin 1929, il épousa à Toronto Edna Mae Brower, puis le 8 décembre 1953, dans la même ville, Olive Evangeline Freeman, veuve de Harry Palmer; aucun enfant ne naquit de ces mariages ; décédé le 16 août 1979 à Ottawa. [1]

War Record

Before CEF enlistment in Aug 1916, while a law student he served with 105th Regiment (Saskatoon Fusiliers), (today the Wikipedia: North Saskatchewan Regiment.

Spent some time the hospital for cardiac-related issues. Arrived in England in Oct 1916, where he was attached to the 196th Battalion (Western Universities), CEF from the General List in Dec 1916, and later 19th Reserve Battalion in late Jan 1917. His cardiac problems persisted, he was returned to Canada and was struck off strength from the CEF in Feb 1917 as medically unfit. he was placed on reserve and allowed to keep rank of Lieutenant after retiring in 1921.[2]

Sources

↑ Denis Smith, “DIEFENBAKER, JOHN GEORGE,” Dictionary of Canadian Biography, vol. 20, University of Toronto/Université Laval, 2003

↑ Great War personnel records. http://central.bac-lac.gc.ca/.item/?op=pdf&app=CEF&id=2514-75
